PARA vs PARA QUE

ğŸ¯ Meaning

Both para and para que express purpose / intention, but the grammar changes depending on the subject.

âœ… **1. PARA + infinitivo**

ğŸ‘‰ Use when both parts of the sentence have the same subject.
ğŸ‘‰ English: â€œin order toâ€¦â€

**Examples**

  • Estudio espaÃ±ol para viajar a Colombia.
    I study Spanish in order to travel to Colombia.

  • Trabajo para tener mÃ¡s dinero.
    I work in order to have more money.

  • Te llamo para hablar contigo.
    I call you in order to talk with you.

Structure:
PARA + infinitive

âœ… **2. PARA QUE + subjuntivo**

ğŸ‘‰ Use when the two parts of the sentence have different subjects.
ğŸ‘‰ English: â€œso thatâ€¦â€ / â€œin order thatâ€¦â€

**Examples**

  • Estudio espaÃ±ol para que mi madre estÃ© orgullosa de mÃ­.
    I study Spanish so that my mother is proud of me.

  • Te llamo para que vayas a comprar.
    I call you so that you go and buy.

  • Trabajo para que mis hijos vivan mejor.
    I work so that my children live better.

Structure:
PARA QUE + subjunctive

ğŸ§  Grammar Summary Table

Situation Spanish English Verb Form
Same subject para + infinitivo in order to infinitive
Different subjects para que + subjuntivo so that subjunctive
